reference: Ponte Milvio, also known as Milvian Bridge, is a historic bridge over the Tiber river in northern Rome, Italy. It was originally constructed in 206 BC by consul Gaius Claudius Nero. It is famous for the Battle of Milvian Bridge in 312 AD, where Emperor Constantine I defeated Maxentius, a victory which helped Constantine become the sole ruler of the Roman Empire and led to his conversion to Christianity. In modern times, Ponte Milvio has become a popular tourist destination and cultural landmark in Rome. An interesting contemporary tradition involving the bridge is the practice where couples attach padlocks, commonly known as 'love locks', to the bridge and throw the keys into the Tiber River as a symbol of their love.

The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States. The Grand Canyon is 277 miles (446 km) long, up to 18 miles (29 km) wide, and attains a depth of over a mile (6,093 feet or 1,857 meters). The canyon and adjacent rim are contained within Grand Canyon National Park, the Kaibab National Forest, Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument, the Hualapai Indian Reservation, the Havasupai Indian Reservation, and the Navajo Nation. President Theodore Roosevelt was a major proponent of the preservation of the Grand Canyon area, and the Grand Canyon was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979. It is known for its visually overwhelming size and its intricate and colorful landscape. Nearly two billion years of Earth's geological history have been exposed as the Colorado River and its tributaries cut their channels through layer after layer of rock.

reference: Niagara Falls is a group of three waterfalls at the southern end of Niagara Gorge, spanning the border between the province of Ontario in Canada and the state of New York in the United States. The largest of the three is Horseshoe Falls, also known as the Canadian Falls, which straddles the international border of the two countries. The smaller American Falls and Bridal Veil Falls lie entirely within the United States. The falls are renowned for their beauty and are both a valuable source of hydroelectric power and a challenging project for environmental preservation. They were formed during the last ice age, when the receding glaciers carved out the Great Lakes and the Niagara River. About 12,000 years ago, water from the newly formed Great Lakes breached a rock ridge and began to flow downwards along what is now known as the Niagara River. The falls are 27 km (17 mi) north-northwest of Buffalo, New York, and 121 km (75 mi) south-southeast of Toronto, between the twin cities of Niagara Falls, Ontario, and Niagara Falls, New York.

Q&A.answer: The receding glaciers during the last ice age, around 12,000 years ago, which carved out the Great Lakes and the Niagara River.

reference: The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210–209 BCE with the purpose of protecting the emperor in his afterlife. The figures, which vary in height according to their roles, include warriors, chariots, and horses. Estimates from 2007 were that the three pits containing the Terracotta Army held more than 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses, and 150 cavalry horses, the majority still buried in the pits near Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province. Other non-military figures were found in other pits, including officials, acrobats, strongmen, and musicians.

reference: The Potala Palace is a dzong fortress in Lhasa, Tibet. It was the chief residence of the Dalai Lama until the 14th Dalai Lama fled to India during the 1959 Tibetan uprising. It is known for its massive white and red walls and is perched on Marpo Ri, the 'Red Hill', which rises 130 meters (about 426 feet) in the Lhasa valley. The structure itself is 170 meters (about 558 feet) in height. The building measures approximately 400 meters east-west and 350 meters north-south. The palace is a model of Tibetan architecture with its successive parts of white, red, and golden roofs, and houses more than 1,000 rooms, 10,000 shrines, and about 200,000 statues.

reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy. It was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles, including animal hunts, executions, and mock sea battles. The construction of the Colosseum began under the emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 by his successor, Titus. reference: The Grand Canal in Venice is one of the major water-traffic corridors in the city. It forms a large reverse-S shape through the central districts (sestieri) of Venice. The canal is 3.8 km long and 30-90 meters wide, with an average depth of five meters. It is flanked by more than 170 buildings, most of which date from the 13th to the 18th centuries, showcasing the wealth and art created by the Republic of Venice. This waterway has been a vital part of Venetian life, used both as a route for boats and gondolas and a setting for water parades and other festivities.

Q&A.answer: It is used as a route for boats and gondolas and as a setting for water parades and other festivities.

reference: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza pyramid complex. It is believed to have been constructed as a tomb for the Egyptian pharaoh Khufu. Completed around 2560 BC, the Great Pyramid originally stood at 146.6 meters (481 feet), but over time, it has lost some of its height. It remains one of the most enduring symbols of Ancient Egypt and one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Archaeologists estimate that it took about 20 years to build and involved a workforce of tens of thousands of people.

reference: Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and the largest religious monument in the world, on a site measuring 162.6 hectares (1.626 km2). Originally constructed as a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu for the Khmer Empire, it was gradually transformed into a Buddhist temple towards the end of the 12th century. It was built by the Khmer King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century in Yasodharapura (present-day Angkor), the capital of the Khmer Empire, as his state temple and eventual mausoleum. Breaking from the Shaiva tradition of previous kings, Angkor Wat was instead dedicated to Vishnu. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious center since its foundation. The temple is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors.

reference: Hagia Sophia, also known as Ayasofya in Turkish, is a historical architectural masterpiece in Istanbul, Turkey. Originally built as a cathedral in 537 AD by Byzantine Emperor Justinian I, it was the world's largest cathedral and an engineering marvel of its time. Following the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople in 1453, it was converted into a mosque by Sultan Mehmed II. In 1935, Kemal Atatürk, the founder of modern Turkey, transformed Hagia Sophia into a museum. In July 2020, it was reconverted into a mosque. Despite these changes, Hagia Sophia remains a significant cultural and architectural symbol, blending elements of both Christian and Islamic art and heritage. The structure is renowned for its massive dome, intricate mosaics, and its historical significance that spans several eras of human civilization.

Q&A.answer: Its massive dome and intricate mosaics

reference: Mount Fuji is the highest mountain in Japan, standing at 3,776.24 meters (12,389.2 feet). An active stratovolcano that last erupted in 1707–1708, Mount Fuji lies about 100 kilometers (62 mi) southwest of Tokyo and can be seen from there on clear days. Mount Fuji’s exceptionally symmetrical cone, which is snow-capped for about five months of the year, is a well-known symbol of Japan and it is frequently depicted in art and photographs. UNESCO recognized Mount Fuji as a Cultural Heritage Site in 2013. The mountain transfers across the borders of the Yamanashi and Shizuoka Prefectures. The area surrounding Mount Fuji is a national park and a popular destination for tourists and hikers alike. Several routes lead to the summit, with over 200,000 people climbing it each year during the summer climbing season in July and August.

reference: Victoria Falls is a waterfall on the Zambezi River in southern Africa, which provides habitat for several unique species of plants and animals. It is located on the border between Zambia and Zimbabwe and is considered one of the world's largest and most famous waterfalls. Described as one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World, it is roughly twice the height of North America's Niagara Falls and is one and a half times wider. The falls are known locally as 'Mosi-oa-Tunya' which means 'The Smoke That Thunders'. The falls span over 1,700 meters in width and drop approximately 100 meters into the Zambezi Gorge. The nearby town of Livingstone in Zambia and Victoria Falls town in Zimbabwe are the two main access points for visitors.

What is the local name for the waterfall depicted in the image?

Q&A.answer: Livingstone in Zambia and Victoria Falls town in Zimbabwe.

reference: Borobudur is a 9th-century Mahayana Buddhist temple in Magelang Regency, not far from the town of Muntilan, in Central Java, Indonesia. It is the world's largest Buddhist temple and consists of nine stacked platforms, six square and three circular, topped by a central dome. The temple is decorated with 2,672 relief panels and 504 Buddha statues. The central dome is surrounded by 72 Buddha statues, each seated inside a perforated stupa. It was built in the 9th century during the reign of the Sailendra Dynasty and designed in Javanese Buddhist architecture, which blends the Indonesian indigenous cult of ancestor worship and the Buddhist concept of attaining Nirvana. Borobudur remains a place for Buddhist pilgrimage. Once a year, Buddhists in Indonesia celebrate Vesak at the monument, and Borobudur is Indonesia's single most visited tourist attraction.

Q&A.question: Where is the location in the image situated?
Q&A.answer: It is situated in Magelang Regency, not far from Muntilan, in Central Java, Indonesia.

Q&A.question: What is the significance of the structure visible in the image?
Q&A.answer: It is the world's largest Buddhist temple.

Q&A.question: During which dynasty was the structure in the image built?
Q&A.answer: It was built during the reign of the Sailendra Dynasty in the 9th century.

reference: The Tower of London, officially Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress of the Tower of London, is a historic castle located on the north bank of the River Thames in central London. Founded towards the end of 1066 as part of the Norman Conquest of England, it was built by William the Conqueror. The White Tower, which gives the entire castle its name, was built by 1078, and was a resented symbol of oppression inflicted upon London by the new ruling elite. Throughout its history, the Tower has served variously as a royal residence, armory, treasury, menagerie, the home of the Royal Mint, a public record office, and the home of the Crown Jewels of England. The Tower was besieged several times, and controlling it has been important to controlling the country. The peak period of the castle's use was from the 11th century until the late 16th century. It is a World Heritage Site and one of the nation's leading historic tourist attractions.

reference: The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex located in Granada, Andalusia, Spain. It was originally constructed as a small fortress in AD 889 on the remains of Roman fortifications, and then largely ignored until its ruins were renovated and rebuilt in the mid-13th century by the Nasrid emir Mohammed ben Al-Ahmar of the Emirate of Granada, who built its current palace and walls. It was converted into a royal palace in 1333 by Yusuf I, Sultan of Granada. The Alhambra is a renowned example of Moorish architecture and is a UNESCO World Heritage site, attracting millions of visitors each year with its rich history, intricate interiors, and stunning gardens.

reference: Blue Lagoon is a geothermal spa located in the Reykjanes Peninsula in southwestern Iceland. The lagoon is situated in a lava field near Grindavík and is renowned for its milky-blue, mineral-rich seawater, which is drawn up from nearly 2,000 meters below the Earth's surface. The water contains silica and sulfur and is used for both recreational bathing and purported skin treatments. The spa is one of the most visited tourist attractions in Iceland and offers a range of amenities including in-water massages, saunas, and a luxury retreat hotel.

reference: The Matterhorn is a mountain of the Alps, straddling the main watershed and border between Switzerland and Italy. It is a large, near-symmetrical pyramidal peak in the extended Monte Rosa area of the Pennine Alps, whose summit is 4,478 meters (14,692 ft) high, making it one of the highest summits in the Alps and Europe. The mountain overlooks the Swiss town of Zermatt in the canton of Valais to the northeast and the Italian town of Breuil-Cervinia in the Aosta Valley to the south. The Matterhorn was the last great Alpine peak to be climbed, marking the end of the golden age of Alpinism, and its first ascent was on 14 July 1865 by Edward Whymper and his party. Since then, it has attracted many climbers and tourists from all over the world.

reference: The Palace of Versailles is a former royal residence located in Versailles, France. It was originally a hunting lodge built in 1623 by Louis XIII and was expanded into a grand palace by his son, Louis XIV, who moved the royal court and government there in 1682. The palace is renowned for its opulent architecture, lavish gardens, and significant role in French history. The Hall of Mirrors, the Royal Opera, and the extensive gardens designed by André Le Nôtre are among its most famous features. The Palace of Versailles was a symbol of the absolute monarchy and played a crucial role in various historical events, including the signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919 that ended World War I.

reference: Westminster Abbey, formally titled the Collegiate Church of Saint Peter at Westminster, is an iconic Gothic abbey church located in the City of Westminster, London, England. It is one of the United Kingdom's most notable religious buildings and traditionally the place of coronation and burial site for English and, later, British monarchs. Though a church was originally founded on the site in the 7th century, the current Gothic structure was begun in 1245 under the order of Henry III. Since 1066, the abbey has been the site of every English and British coronation, and it has witnessed numerous significant royal events. Westminster Abbey also holds the graves of notable individuals such as Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, and Geoffrey Chaucer, making it a site of great historical and cultural significance.

reference: The Brandenburg Gate is an 18th-century neoclassical monument in Berlin, built on the orders of Prussian king Frederick William II after the temporary restoration of order during the Batavian Revolution. It was completed by Carl Gotthard Langhans in 1791 and is one of the most well-known landmarks of Germany. It stands at the western end of the Unter den Linden boulevard, which was the road to the Prussian palace. The gate consists of twelve Doric columns, six to each side, forming five passages. The central and wider passage was used by the royals, the adjacent passages were for the aristocracy, and the outer two passages were for the public. The gate was a symbol of division during the Cold War and is now considered a symbol of unity and peace.

reference: Lake Como, also known as Lario, is a lake of glacial origin in Lombardy, Italy. It has an area of 146 square kilometers, making it the third largest lake in Italy, after Lake Garda and Lake Maggiore. At over 400 meters deep, it is one of the deepest lakes in Europe. The shores of Lake Como are characterized by charming villages, luxurious villas, and scenic landscapes, which contribute to its reputation as a desirable tourist destination. The city of Como is located at the southwestern end of the lake. Como is a significant tourist and cultural attraction, known for its Gothic cathedral, museums, and funicular railway leading to the village of Brunate. Moreover, Lake Como has been a popular retreat for aristocrats and the wealthy since Roman times, and it is surrounded by many villas and palaces such as Villa Olmo, Villa Serbelloni, and Villa Carlotta.

reference: Marina Bay Sands is an integrated resort fronting Marina Bay within the Downtown Core district of Singapore. At its opening in 2010, it was billed as the world's most expensive standalone casino property at S$8 billion (including the cost of the land). The resort includes a hotel with three towers topped by a sky park, a convention-exhibition centre, the Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands mall, an ArtScience Museum, two large theatres, celebrity chef restaurants, floating Crystal Pavilions, and a large casino with 500 tables and 1,600 slot machines. The complex is owned by the Las Vegas Sands Corporation and was designed by Israeli architect Moshe Safdie. reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an ancient amphitheatre in Rome, Italy. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Construction began under Emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 under his successor and heir, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96 AD). The Colosseum could hold an estimated 50,000 to 80,000 spectators and was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. Despite being damaged by earthquakes and stone-robbers, the Colosseum remains an iconic symbol of Imperial Rome and is listed as one of the New7Wonders of the World.

reference: The Statue of David is a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture created by Michelangelo between 1501 and 1504. The statue represents the Biblical hero David and was originally commissioned as one of a series of statues of prophets to be positioned along the roofline of the Florence Cathedral. However, it was instead placed in a public square, outside the Palazzo della Signoria (also known as Palazzo Vecchio), the seat of civic government in Florence, in the Piazza della Signoria. The statue was moved to the Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence in 1873, where it has become one of the most renowned works of the Renaissance period. A replica now stands in its original location in the Piazza della Signoria.

reference: The Sydney Opera House is a multi-venue performing arts centre in Sydney, Australia. It was designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon but completed by an Australian architectural team headed by Peter Hall. The building was formally opened on 20 October 1973. Situated on Bennelong Point in Sydney Harbour, close to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, it is one of the 20th century's most famous and distinctive buildings. The Opera House hosts more than 1,500 performances annually, attended by more than 1.2 million people. It comprises multiple venues, including a Concert Hall, Joan Sutherland Theatre, Drama Theatre, Playhouse, and Utzon Room. The facility is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is regarded as one of the world's most iconic landmarks.

reference: Buckingham Palace is the London residence and administrative headquarters of the monarch of the United Kingdom. It became the London residence of the British monarch in 1837, following the accession of Queen Victoria. The palace has 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. reference: Chichen Itza was a large pre-Columbian city built by the Maya people. It is located in the eastern portion of Yucatán state in Mexico. The site exhibits a multitude of architectural styles, reminiscent of styles seen in central Mexico and of the Puuc and Chenes styles of the Northern Maya lowlands. The site includes a large pyramid known as El Castillo or Temple of Kukulcan, the Great Ball Court, and the Temple of the Warriors, among other buildings. It was one of the largest Maya cities and is believed to have been one of the mythical great cities, or Tollans, referred to in Mesoamerican literature. The ruins of Chichen Itza are federal property, and the site's stewardship is maintained by Mexico's Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (National Institute of Anthropology and History). Chichen Itza is one of the most visited archaeological sites in Mexico; an estimated 2.6 million tourists visit the ruins every year. In 1988, it was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and it was also named one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in a 2007 global poll.

Q&A.question: What civilization built the city in the image?
Q&A.answer: The Maya civilization built the city.

Q&A.answer: The large pyramid is called El Castillo or Temple of Kukulcan.

Q&A.question: When was the site in the image designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site?
Q&A.answer: The site was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988.

reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an ancient amphitheatre in the centre of Rome, Italy. It is the largest ancient amphitheatre ever built and is still the largest standing amphitheatre in the world today, despite its age. Construction began under the emperor Vespasian in AD 72, and it was completed in AD 80 under his successor and heir, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96). The Colosseum could hold, it is estimated, between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators, having an average audience of some 65,000; it was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. This included animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on classical mythology. The building ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era.

Q&A.answer: For gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.

Q&A.answer: Between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators, with an average of 65,000.

reference: The Giza pyramid complex is located on the Giza Plateau near Cairo, Egypt. It includes three main pyramids: the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure. The complex also features several smaller satellite pyramids, temples, a workers' village, and the Great Sphinx. The Great Pyramid, also known as the Pyramid of Khufu, is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and the only one to remain largely intact. It was built during Egypt’s Fourth Dynasty, around 2580–2560 BC, and was originally 146.6 meters tall. The Sphinx is a limestone statue with the body of a lion and the head of a human, believed to represent Pharaoh Khafre. The Giza Plateau has been a significant archaeological and tourist site for centuries, attracting visitors from around the world.

The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States. The Grand Canyon is 277 miles (446 km) long, up to 18 miles (29 km) wide, and attains a depth of over a mile (6,093 feet or 1,857 meters). The canyon and adjacent rim are contained within Grand Canyon National Park, the Kaibab National Forest, Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument, the Hualapai Indian Reservation, the Havasupai Indian Reservation, and the Navajo Nation. President Theodore Roosevelt was a major proponent of the preservation of the Grand Canyon area, and the Grand Canyon was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979. It is known for its visually overwhelming size and its intricate and colorful landscape. Nearly two billion years of Earth's geological history have been exposed as the Colorado River and its tributaries cut their channels through layer after layer of rock.

reference: Niagara Falls is a group of three waterfalls at the southern end of Niagara Gorge, spanning the border between the province of Ontario in Canada and the state of New York in the United States. The largest of the three is Horseshoe Falls, also known as the Canadian Falls, which straddles the international border of the two countries. The smaller American Falls and Bridal Veil Falls lie entirely within the United States. The falls are renowned for their beauty and are both a valuable source of hydroelectric power and a challenging project for environmental preservation. They were formed during the last ice age, when the receding glaciers carved out the Great Lakes and the Niagara River. About 12,000 years ago, water from the newly formed Great Lakes breached a rock ridge and began to flow downwards along what is now known as the Niagara River. The falls are 27 km (17 mi) north-northwest of Buffalo, New York, and 121 km (75 mi) south-southeast of Toronto, between the twin cities of Niagara Falls, Ontario, and Niagara Falls, New York.

Q&A.question: Where is the location depicted in the image situated?
Q&A.answer: At the southern end of Niagara Gorge, on the border between Ontario, Canada, and New York, United States.

Q&A.answer: Three waterfalls: Horseshoe Falls, American Falls, and Bridal Veil Falls.

Q&A.question: What significant geological event led to the formation of the site shown in the image?
Q&A.answer: The receding glaciers during the last ice age, around 12,000 years ago, which carved out the Great Lakes and the Niagara River.

The wall began construction in the 3rd century BC, with major enhancements and rebuilding occurring during the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644). A UNESCO World Heritage site since 1987, it symbolizes China's historical resilience and engineering ingenuity.

reference: The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210–209 BCE with the purpose of protecting the emperor in his afterlife. The figures, which vary in height according to their roles, include warriors, chariots, and horses. Estimates from 2007 were that the three pits containing the Terracotta Army held more than 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses, and 150 cavalry horses, the majority still buried in the pits near Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province. Other non-military figures were found in other pits, including officials, acrobats, strongmen, and musicians.

reference: Jiuzhaigou Valley is a nature reserve and national park located in the Aba Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous Prefecture of Sichuan Province, China. Known for its multi-level waterfalls, colorful lakes, and snow-capped peaks, Jiuzhaigou Valley is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The valley is part of the Min Mountains and stretches over 72,000 hectares. It is famous for its blue, green, and turquoise-colored lakes, which are often surrounded by pristine forests. This area is also home to a variety of endangered plant and animal species, including the giant panda and the Sichuan golden monkey.

reference: Lijiang Ancient Town, also known as Dayan Ancient Town, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Lijiang City, Yunnan Province, China. The town is noted for its well-preserved ancient buildings and the unique culture of the Nakhi people who inhabit the area. Established during the late Song Dynasty and early Yuan Dynasty, it has a history spanning over 800 years. The town is famed for its traditional architecture, intricate waterways, and bridges. It is also a key location on the Ancient Tea Horse Road, an important trade route that historically connected China with Tibet and other regions.

reference: The Potala Palace is a dzong fortress in Lhasa, Tibet. It was the chief residence of the Dalai Lama until the 14th Dalai Lama fled to India during the 1959 Tibetan uprising. The palace is named after Mount Potalaka, the mythical abode of the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara. The Potala Palace is now a museum and World Heritage Site. It is known for its massive white and red walls and is perched on Marpo Ri, the 'Red Hill', which rises 130 meters (about 426 feet) in the Lhasa valley. The structure itself is 170 meters (about 558 feet) in height. The building measures approximately 400 meters east-west and 350 meters north-south. The palace is a model of Tibetan architecture with its successive parts of white, red, and golden roofs, and houses more than 1,000 rooms, 10,000 shrines, and about 200,000 statues.

reference: Mount Tai, or Tai Shan, is a mountain of historical and cultural significance located north of the city of Tai'an, in Shandong province, China. It has been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1987 due to its cultural importance. Many famous emperors, poets, and scholars have visited Mount Tai, contributing to its rich historical heritage. reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy. Built of travertine limestone, tuff (volcanic rock), and brick-faced concrete, it was the largest amphitheatre ever built at the time and held between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators. It was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles, including animal hunts, executions, and mock sea battles. The construction of the Colosseum began under the emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 by his successor, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96 AD). Although partially ruined due to earthquakes and stone robbers, the Colosseum is still an iconic symbol of Imperial Rome and is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the city.

Constructed from 1887 to 1889 as the entrance arch for the 1889 World's Fair, it was initially criticized by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design. However, it has become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognizable structures in the world. The tower is 330 meters tall, making it the tallest structure in Paris. It was the tallest man-made structure in the world for 41 years until the completion of the Chrysler Building in New York in 1930. The Eiffel Tower is one of the most-visited paid monuments in the world; 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015.

reference: The Sydney Opera House is a multi-venue performing arts centre in Sydney. It is one of the 20th century's most famous and distinctive buildings. Designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon, the building was formally opened on 20 October 1973 after a gestation beginning with Utzon's 1957 selection as winner of an international design competition. The Government of New South Wales, led by the Premier, Joseph Cahill, authorised work to begin in 1958 with Utzon directing construction. The government’s decision to build Utzon's design is often overshadowed by politics, budget overruns, and construction difficulties that followed. The building and its surrounds occupy the whole of Bennelong Point on Sydney Harbour, between Sydney Cove and Farm Cove, adjacent to the Royal Botanic Gardens, and close by the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

reference: Christ the Redeemer is an iconic statue of Jesus Christ located in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It stands 30 meters (98 feet) tall, excluding its 8-meter (26-foot) pedestal, and its arms stretch 28 meters (92 feet) wide. The statue is situated at the peak of the 700-meter (2,300-foot) Corcovado mountain in the Tijuca National Park, offering panoramic views of the city. Designed by French sculptor Paul Landowski and created by Brazilian engineer Heitor da Silva Costa in collaboration with French engineer Albert Caquot, the statue was constructed between 1922 and 1931. Christ the Redeemer is a symbol of Christianity across the world and a cultural icon of both Rio de Janeiro and Brazil, attracting millions of visitors annually. It was declared one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in 2007.

reference: Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument located in Wiltshire, England, near the city of Salisbury. Stonehenge is considered one of the most famous landmarks in the United Kingdom. It has been legally protected since 1882 and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, listed in 1986. reference: Machu Picchu is a 15th-century Inca citadel located in the Eastern Cordillera of southern Peru, on a mountain ridge 2,430 meters (7,970 ft) above sea level. It is located in the Cusco Region, Urubamba Province, Machupicchu District in Peru. Often mistaken as the 'Lost City of the Incas', it is one of the most recognizable symbols of the Inca civilization. The site was built around 1450 during the reign of the Inca emperor Pachacuti. In 1981 it was designated a Peruvian Historic Sanctuary and in 1983 a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Machu Picchu is divided into an urban sector and an agricultural sector, featuring temples, terraces, and water channels. It is believed to have been abandoned during the Spanish Conquest. The site was brought to international attention by American historian Hiram Bingham in 1911.

reference: Notre-Dame de Paris, often referred to simply as Notre-Dame, is a medieval Catholic cathedral on the Île de la Cité in the 4th arrondissement of Paris, France. reference: The Louvre Museum, or simply the Louvre, is the world's most visited museum and a historic monument in Paris, France. It is known for housing the famous painting, the Mona Lisa. Situated on the Right Bank of the Seine, the Louvre Palace, which houses the museum, was originally built as a fortress in the late 12th to 13th century under Philip II. The building was transformed into a royal palace in the 16th century and later converted into a public museum in 1793 during the French Revolution. The museum's collection is vast, encompassing works from ancient civilizations to the mid-19th century. The iconic glass pyramid entrance was designed by architect I. M. Pei and inaugurated in 1989 as part of an expansion project.

Q&A.answer: It was built as a fortress.

reference: The Grand Canal in Venice is one of the major water-traffic corridors in the city. It forms a large reverse-S shape through the central districts (sestieri) of Venice. The canal is 3.8 km long and 30-90 meters wide, with an average depth of five meters. It is flanked by more than 170 buildings, most of which date from the 13th to the 18th centuries, showcasing the wealth and art created by the Republic of Venice. This waterway has been a vital part of Venetian life, used both as a route for boats and gondolas and a setting for water parades and other festivities.

Q&A.answer: It is used as a route for boats and gondolas and as a setting for water parades and other festivities.

reference: Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and the largest religious monument in the world, on a site measuring 162.6 hectares (1.626 km2). Originally constructed as a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu for the Khmer Empire, it was gradually transformed into a Buddhist temple towards the end of the 12th century. It was built by the Khmer King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century in Yasodharapura (present-day Angkor), the capital of the Khmer Empire, as his state temple and eventual mausoleum. Breaking from the Shaiva tradition of previous kings, Angkor Wat was instead dedicated to Vishnu. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious center since its foundation. The temple is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors.

reference: Hagia Sophia, also known as Ayasofya in Turkish, is a historical architectural masterpiece in Istanbul, Turkey. Originally built as a cathedral in 537 AD by Byzantine Emperor Justinian I, it was the world's largest cathedral and an engineering marvel of its time. Following the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople in 1453, it was converted into a mosque by Sultan Mehmed II. In 1935, Kemal Atatürk, the founder of modern Turkey, transformed Hagia Sophia into a museum. In July 2020, it was reconverted into a mosque. Despite these changes, Hagia Sophia remains a significant cultural and architectural symbol, blending elements of both Christian and Islamic art and heritage. The structure is renowned for its massive dome, intricate mosaics, and its historical significance that spans several eras of human civilization.

reference: Mount Fuji is the highest mountain in Japan, standing at 3,776.24 meters (12,389.2 feet). An active stratovolcano that last erupted in 1707–1708, Mount Fuji lies about 100 kilometers (62 mi) southwest of Tokyo and can be seen from there on clear days. Mount Fuji’s exceptionally symmetrical cone, which is snow-capped for about five months of the year, is a well-known symbol of Japan and it is frequently depicted in art and photographs. UNESCO recognized Mount Fuji as a Cultural Heritage Site in 2013. The mountain transfers across the borders of the Yamanashi and Shizuoka Prefectures. The area surrounding Mount Fuji is a national park and a popular destination for tourists and hikers alike. Several routes lead to the summit, with over 200,000 people climbing it each year during the summer climbing season in July and August.

reference: Borobudur is a 9th-century Mahayana Buddhist temple in Magelang Regency, not far from the town of Muntilan, in Central Java, Indonesia. It is the world's largest Buddhist temple and consists of nine stacked platforms, six square and three circular, topped by a central dome. The temple is decorated with 2,672 relief panels and 504 Buddha statues. The central dome is surrounded by 72 Buddha statues, each seated inside a perforated stupa. It was built in the 9th century during the reign of the Sailendra Dynasty and designed in Javanese Buddhist architecture, which blends the Indonesian indigenous cult of ancestor worship and the Buddhist concept of attaining Nirvana. Borobudur remains a place for Buddhist pilgrimage. Once a year, Buddhists in Indonesia celebrate Vesak at the monument, and Borobudur is Indonesia's single most visited tourist attraction.

Q&A.question: Where is the location in the image situated?
Q&A.answer: It is situated in Magelang Regency, not far from Muntilan, in Central Java, Indonesia.

Q&A.question: What is the significance of the structure visible in the image?
Q&A.answer: It is the world's largest Buddhist temple.

Q&A.question: During which dynasty was the structure in the image built?
Q&A.answer: It was built during the reign of the Sailendra Dynasty in the 9th century.

reference: The Tower of London, officially Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress of the Tower of London, is a historic castle located on the north bank of the River Thames in central London. Founded towards the end of 1066 as part of the Norman Conquest of England, it was built by William the Conqueror. The White Tower, which gives the entire castle its name, was built by 1078, and was a resented symbol of oppression inflicted upon London by the new ruling elite. Throughout its history, the Tower has served variously as a royal residence, armory, treasury, menagerie, the home of the Royal Mint, a public record office, and the home of the Crown Jewels of England. The Tower was besieged several times, and controlling it has been important to controlling the country. The peak period of the castle's use was from the 11th century until the late 16th century. It is a World Heritage Site and one of the nation's leading historic tourist attractions.

reference: The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex located in Granada, Andalusia, Spain. It was originally constructed as a small fortress in AD 889 on the remains of Roman fortifications, and then largely ignored until its ruins were renovated and rebuilt in the mid-13th century by the Nasrid emir Mohammed ben Al-Ahmar of the Emirate of Granada, who built its current palace and walls. It was converted into a royal palace in 1333 by Yusuf I, Sultan of Granada. The Alhambra is a renowned example of Moorish architecture and is a UNESCO World Heritage site, attracting millions of visitors each year with its rich history, intricate interiors, and stunning gardens.

reference: The Matterhorn is a mountain of the Alps, straddling the main watershed and border between Switzerland and Italy. It is a large, near-symmetrical pyramidal peak in the extended Monte Rosa area of the Pennine Alps, whose summit is 4,478 meters (14,692 ft) high, making it one of the highest summits in the Alps and Europe. The mountain overlooks the Swiss town of Zermatt in the canton of Valais to the northeast and the Italian town of Breuil-Cervinia in the Aosta Valley to the south. The Matterhorn was the last great Alpine peak to be climbed, marking the end of the golden age of Alpinism, and its first ascent was on 14 July 1865 by Edward Whymper and his party. Since then, it has attracted many climbers and tourists from all over the world.

reference: The Palace of Versailles is a former royal residence located in Versailles, France. It was originally a hunting lodge built in 1623 by Louis XIII and was expanded into a grand palace by his son, Louis XIV, who moved the royal court and government there in 1682. The palace is renowned for its opulent architecture, lavish gardens, and significant role in French history. The Hall of Mirrors, the Royal Opera, and the extensive gardens designed by André Le Nôtre are among its most famous features. reference: Westminster Abbey, formally titled the Collegiate Church of Saint Peter at Westminster, is an iconic Gothic abbey church located in the City of Westminster, London, England. It is one of the United Kingdom's most notable religious buildings and traditionally the place of coronation and burial site for English and, later, British monarchs. Though a church was originally founded on the site in the 7th century, the current Gothic structure was begun in 1245 under the order of Henry III. Since 1066, the abbey has been the site of every English and British coronation, and it has witnessed numerous significant royal events. Westminster Abbey also holds the graves of notable individuals such as Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, and Geoffrey Chaucer, making it a site of great historical and cultural significance.

reference: The Brandenburg Gate is an 18th-century neoclassical monument in Berlin, built on the orders of Prussian king Frederick William II after the temporary restoration of order during the Batavian Revolution. It was completed by Carl Gotthard Langhans in 1791 and is one of the most well-known landmarks of Germany. It stands at the western end of the Unter den Linden boulevard, which was the road to the Prussian palace. The gate consists of twelve Doric columns, six to each side, forming five passages. The central and wider passage was used by the royals, the adjacent passages were for the aristocracy, and the outer two passages were for the public. The gate was a symbol of division during the Cold War and is now considered a symbol of unity and peace.

reference: Lake Como, also known as Lario, is a lake of glacial origin in Lombardy, Italy. It has an area of 146 square kilometers, making it the third largest lake in Italy, after Lake Garda and Lake Maggiore. At over 400 meters deep, it is one of the deepest lakes in Europe. The shores of Lake Como are characterized by charming villages, luxurious villas, and scenic landscapes, which contribute to its reputation as a desirable tourist destination. The city of Como is located at the southwestern end of the lake. Como is a significant tourist and cultural attraction, known for its Gothic cathedral, museums, and funicular railway leading to the village of Brunate. Moreover, Lake Como has been a popular retreat for aristocrats and the wealthy since Roman times, and it is surrounded by many villas and palaces such as Villa Olmo, Villa Serbelloni, and Villa Carlotta.

reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an ancient amphitheatre in Rome, Italy. It is one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. Construction began under Emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 under his successor and heir, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96 AD). The Colosseum could hold an estimated 50,000 to 80,000 spectators and was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles, such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. Despite being damaged by earthquakes and stone-robbers, the Colosseum remains an iconic symbol of Imperial Rome and is listed as one of the New7Wonders of the World.

The statue was moved to the Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence in 1873, where it has become one of the most renowned works of the Renaissance period. reference: Chichen Itza was a large pre-Columbian city built by the Maya people. It is located in the eastern portion of Yucatán state in Mexico. The site exhibits a multitude of architectural styles, reminiscent of styles seen in central Mexico and of the Puuc and Chenes styles of the Northern Maya lowlands. The site includes a large pyramid known as El Castillo or Temple of Kukulcan, the Great Ball Court, and the Temple of the Warriors, among other buildings. It was one of the largest Maya cities and is believed to have been one of the mythical great cities, or Tollans, referred to in Mesoamerican literature. The ruins of Chichen Itza are federal property, and the site's stewardship is maintained by Mexico's Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (National Institute of Anthropology and History). Chichen Itza is one of the most visited archaeological sites in Mexico; an estimated 2.6 million tourists visit the ruins every year. In 1988, it was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and it was also named one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in a 2007 global poll.

Q&A.answer: The Maya civilization built the city.

reference: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It was named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower. Constructed from 1887 to 1889 as the entrance arch for the 1889 World's Fair, it is 324 meters tall and was the tallest man-made structure in the world until the completion of the Chrysler Building in New York in 1930. The Eiffel Tower is one of the most recognizable structures in the world and a global cultural icon of France. It is also one of the most-visited paid monuments in the world, receiving millions of visitors annually.

reference: The Giza pyramid complex is located on the Giza Plateau near Cairo, Egypt. It includes three main pyramids: the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure. The complex also features several smaller satellite pyramids, temples, a workers' village, and the Great Sphinx. The Great Pyramid, also known as the Pyramid of Khufu, is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and the only one to remain largely intact. It was built during Egypt’s Fourth Dynasty, around 2580–2560 BC, and was originally 146.6 meters tall. The Sphinx is a limestone statue with the body of a lion and the head of a human, believed to represent Pharaoh Khafre. The Giza Plateau has been a significant archaeological and tourist site for centuries, attracting visitors from around the world.

Q&A.question: What are the three main pyramids in the image?
Q&A.answer: The Great Pyramid of Giza, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure.

reference: The Sagrada Família is a large unfinished Roman Catholic minor basilica in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Designed by the Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí, his work on the building is part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Despite being under construction since 1882, the Sagrada Família is not completed to this day. It is known for its unique architectural style blending Gothic and Art Nouveau forms. The construction has been slow-paced, relying mainly on private donations and was halted during periods such as the Spanish Civil War. Gaudí devoted the latter part of his life to this project and at the time of his death in 1926, less than a quarter of the project was complete.

reference: The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex located in Granada, Spain. Originally constructed as a small fortress in AD 889 on the remains of Roman fortifications, it was largely ignored until its ruins were renovated and rebuilt in the mid-13th century by the Nasrid emir Mohammed ben Al-Ahmar of the Emirate of Granada, who built its current palace and walls. It was converted into a royal palace in 1333 by Yusuf I, Sultan of Granada. The Alhambra reflects the culture of the last centuries of the Moorish rule over the Iberian Peninsula and is renowned for its Islamic architecture, fostering intricate stucco work, Arabic inscriptions, and its beautiful gardens. After the conclusion of the Christian reconquest in 1492, the Alhambra was partially altered but retained most of its Moorish characteristics.

Q&A.answer: A small fortress constructed in AD 889 on the remains of Roman fortifications.

reference: La Catedral de Sevilla, also known as the Seville Cathedral, is a Roman Catholic cathedral in Seville, Spain. It is the largest Gothic cathedral and the third-largest church in the world. reference: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an ancient amphitheatre in the centre of Rome, Italy. Built of concrete and sand, it is the largest ancient amphitheatre ever built and is considered one of the greatest works of architecture and engineering. Construction began under the emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 under his successor and heir, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96 AD). The Colosseum could hold an estimated 50,000 to 80,000 spectators and was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles such as animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The structure continued to be used for entertainment into the early medieval era. Later, it was reused for such purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry, and a Christian shrine.

reference: Ponte Vecchio is a medieval stone closed-spandrel segmental arch bridge over the Arno River, in Florence, Italy. It is notable for still having shops built along it, as was once common. Butchers initially occupied the shops; the present tenants are jewelers, art dealers, and souvenir sellers. The Ponte Vecchio's two neighboring bridges are the Ponte Santa Trinita and the Ponte alle Grazie. It is believed that the concept of bankruptcy originated here: when a merchant could not pay his debts, the table on which he sold his goods (the 'banco') was physically broken ('rotto') by soldiers, and this practice was called 'bancorotto'.

reference: Yonghe Temple, also known as the Yonghe Lamasery or commonly as the Lama Temple, is a temple and monastery of the Gelug school of Tibetan Buddhism located in the Dongcheng District of Beijing, China. The building and artworks of the temple combine Han Chinese and Tibetan styles. The construction of the Yonghe Temple started in 1694 during the Qing dynasty on the site where originally stood an official residence for court eunuchs of the Ming dynasty. It was then converted into the residence of Yinzhen (Prince Yong), the fourth son of Kangxi, during his time as a prince. In 1722, he became the Yongzheng Emperor, converting half of the complex into a lamasery, while the other half remained an imperial palace. In 1744, the temple was completely transformed into a lamasery and Lama Temple became the national center of Lama administration. The temple survived the Cultural Revolution and was opened to the public in 1981.

The tower is the primary television and radio broadcast site for the Kantō region. Tokyo Skytree was officially opened to the public on May 22, 2012. The tower features an observation deck with views of the city, and it illuminates in different colors at night. It is part of the Tokyo Skytree Town complex, which includes a large shopping mall and an aquarium.

reference: Rikugien Garden is a Tokyo metropolitan park and nationally designated scenic site in Bunkyō, Tokyo. The name Rikugi comes from the idea of the six elements in waka poetry, and 'en' means garden or park. The garden was completed in 1695 and is one of the most beautiful and famous gardens in Tokyo. It was created by Yanagisawa Yoshiyasu and is an excellent example of an Edo period strolling garden. The garden features a central pond, islands, forested areas, man-made hills, and several tea houses. It was donated to the Tokyo City government in 1938 and opened to the public. The best times to visit are in spring for cherry blossoms and autumn for the colorful leaves.

reference: The Texas State Capitol, located in Austin, Texas, is the capitol building and seat of government of the American state of Texas. It houses the chambers of the Texas Legislature and the office of the governor. Designed in 1881 by architect Elijah E. Myers, it was constructed from 1882 to 1888 under the direction of civil engineer Reuben Lindsay Walker. At the time of its opening in 1888, it was the seventh largest building in the world. reference: Mount St. Helens is an active stratovolcano located in Skamania County, Washington, in the United States. reference: The Statue of Liberty is a colossal neoclassical sculpture on Liberty Island in New York Harbor within New York City, in the United States. The copper statue, a gift from the people of France, was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and its metal framework was built by Gustave Eiffel. It was dedicated on October 28, 1886. The statue is a figure of Libertas, a robed Roman liberty goddess who holds a torch above her head with her right hand, and in her left hand carries a tabula ansata inscribed JULY IV MDCCLXXVI (July 4, 1776 in Roman numerals), the date of the U.S. Declaration of Independence. A broken shackle and chain lie at her feet as she moves forward, commemorating the recent national abolition of slavery. After its dedication, the statue became an icon of freedom and of the United States, seen as a symbol of welcome to immigrants arriving by sea. The Statue of Liberty is managed by the National Park Service and has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1984.

The Washington Monument is an obelisk within the National Mall in Washington, D.C., built to commemorate George Washington, once commander-in-chief of the Continental Army and the first president of the United States. The monument, made of marble, granite, and bluestone gneiss, is both the world's tallest predominantly stone structure and the world's tallest obelisk, standing at 554 feet 7 11⁄32 inches (169.046 m). Construction began in 1848 and was halted from 1854 to 1877 due to a lack of funds and the American Civil War; it eventually was completed in 1884. It was opened to the public on October 9, 1888. The cornerstone is made of marble extracted from a quarry outside Baltimore, Maryland. The original construction was by the Washington National Monument Society, followed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, who also oversaw its completion. It is noted for its simplicity, starkness, and prominent location. The monument is made up of two main parts: the base and the shaft, surrounded by a circle of flags representing each U.S. state and territory.

reference: The White House is the official residence and workplace of the president of the United States. Construction took place between 1792 and 1800 using Aquia Creek sandstone painted white. The building has six floors: the Ground Floor, State Floor, Second Floor, and Third Floor, as well as a two-story basement. The property is a National Heritage Site owned by the National Park Service and is part of the President's Park.

reference: The Texas State Capitol is the capitol building and seat of government of the American state of Texas. Located in downtown Austin, Texas, it houses the offices and chambers of the Texas Legislature and the office of the governor. Constructed from 1882 to 1888, it is widely recognized as one of the nation's most distinguished state capitols. The building is known for its distinctive Renaissance Revival architecture and is made predominantly of Texas pink granite. The Capitol was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1970 and recognized as a National Historic Landmark in 1986. Standing at 308 feet (94 meters) tall, it is taller than the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C.

Key features include the Assembly Room where the Second Continental Congress met, and the Liberty Bell was housed there until the 1850s.

reference: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States. reference: Everglades National Park is a U.S. National Park in Florida that protects the southern 20 percent of the original Everglades. Established in 1947, it is the largest tropical wilderness of any kind in the United States and is visited on average by one million people each year. The park contains the largest mangrove ecosystem in the western hemisphere, is the most significant breeding ground for tropical wading birds in North America, and supports threatened and endangered species like the manatee, American crocodile, and the elusive Florida panther. The park covers 1,508,976 acres (6,106.61 km2), making it the third-largest national park in the contiguous United States. It was designated a World Heritage Site in 1979, a Wetland of International Importance in 1987, and an International Biosphere Reserve in 1976.

reference: Mount St. Helens is an active stratovolcano located in Skamania County, Washington, in the United States. It is part of the Cascade Range and is best known for its catastrophic eruption on May 18, 1980, which was the deadliest and most economically destructive volcanic event in U.S. history. The eruption reduced the elevation of the mountain's summit from 9,677 feet to 8,363 feet and replaced it with a one-mile-wide horseshoe-shaped crater. The blast was heard hundreds of miles away, and the ash plume rose to approximately 80,000 feet, affecting areas as far away as Western Montana. Today, Mount St. Helens is a popular destination for tourism and scientific research.

reference: Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a United States National Park and UNESCO World Heritage Site straddling the ridgeline of the Great Smoky Mountains, part of the Blue Ridge Mountains, which are a division of the larger Appalachian Mountain chain. reference: The Yellowstone Caldera, sometimes referred to as the Yellowstone Supervolcano, is a volcanic caldera and supervolcano located in Yellowstone National Park in the U.S. states of Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho. The caldera formed during the last of three supereruptions over the past 2.1 million years: the Huckleberry Ridge eruption 2.1 million years ago, the Mesa Falls eruption 1.3 million years ago, and the Lava Creek eruption approximately 631,000 years ago. It measures approximately 30 by 45 miles (50 by 70 km) and is one of the largest active volcanic systems in the world. The caldera's geothermal features, including the famous Old Faithful geyser and other geothermal activity, attract millions of visitors each year.

reference: Death Valley is a desert valley located in Eastern California, in the northern Mojave Desert, and is the hottest, driest, and lowest national park in the United States. It holds the record for the highest air temperature ever recorded on Earth. Death Valley is bounded by the Panamint Range to the west and the Black Mountains and the Funeral Mountains to the east. The valley was named during the California Gold Rush by prospectors and others who sought to cross the valley on their way to the gold fields even though only one confirmed death occurred here during the rush. During summer, daytime temperatures often exceed 120 °F (49 °C) when staying in the valley. It also features several ghost towns with colorful histories related to the mining era.

reference: Antelope Canyon is a popular slot canyon located on Navajo land east of Page, Arizona. It includes two separate, scenic slot canyon sections: Upper Antelope Canyon (or The Crack) and Lower Antelope Canyon (or The Corkscrew). It was formed by the erosion of Navajo Sandstone, primarily due to flash flooding and other sub-aerial processes. Visitors flock to the canyon for its stunning light beams that shine directly down into the openings of the canyon, creating dramatic photo opportunities. The canyon is also a sacred site to the Navajo people, who offer guided tours and share the cultural significance of the area.

reference: The Statue of Liberty is a colossal neoclassical sculpture on Liberty Island in New York Harbor within New York City, in the United States. The copper statue, a gift from the people of France, was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and its metal framework was built by Gustave Eiffel. It was dedicated on October 28, 1886. The statue is a figure of Libertas, a robed Roman liberty goddess. She holds a torch above her head with her right hand, and in her left hand carries a tabula ansata inscribed JULY IV MDCCLXXVI (July 4, 1776 in Roman numerals). A broken shackle and chain lie at her feet as she walks forward, commemorating the recent national abolition of slavery. The statue became an icon of freedom and of the United States, and was a welcoming sight to immigrants arriving from abroad.

It was recast twice by local workmen John Pass and John Stow, and the subsequent crack occurred sometime in the early 19th century, and the Liberty Bell acquired its distinctive large crack sometime between 1817 and 1846. It was used to summon lawmakers to legislative sessions and alert citizens to public meetings and proclamations. The inscription on the bell reads, 'Proclaim LIBERTY Throughout All the Land Unto All the Inhabitants Thereof Lev. XXV. v X.' The Liberty Bell is housed in the Liberty Bell Center in Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia.

reference: Tower Bridge is a combined bascule and suspension bridge in London, England, over the River Thames. It is close to the Tower of London, from which it takes its name. It was built between 1886 and 1894. The bridge consists of two bridge towers tied together at the upper level by means of two horizontal walkways. The bridge deck is freely accessible to both vehicles and pedestrians, while the bridge's twin towers, high-level walkways, and Victorian engine rooms form part of the Tower Bridge Exhibition. The bridge is 800 feet (240 m) in length, with two towers each 213 feet (65 m) high, built on piers. The central span of 200 feet (61 m) between the towers is split into two equal bascules or leaves, which can be raised to allow river traffic to pass. The bascules were once operated by steam but are now hydraulically powered using oil and electricity. Tower Bridge has become an iconic symbol of London and is sometimes mistakenly referred to as London Bridge, a different bridge entirely located upstream.

reference: The Ponte Vecchio is a medieval stone closed-spandrel segmental arch bridge over the Arno River, in Florence, Italy. It is noted for still having shops built along it, as was once common. Butchers initially occupied the shops; the present tenants are jewelers, art dealers, and souvenir sellers. The bridge spans the Arno River at its narrowest point where it is believed that a bridge was first built in Roman times. It has been described as Europe's oldest, wholly-stone, closed-spandrel segmental arch bridge. During World War II, it was the only bridge across the Arno that the fleeing Germans did not destroy. The bridge is also noted for the Vasari Corridor, an enclosed passageway commissioned in 1565 by Cosimo I de' Medici to allow the Grand Dukes to move from the Pitti Palace to the Uffizi safely.

reference: Buckingham Palace is the London residence and administrative headquarters of the monarch of the United Kingdom. Originally known as Buckingham House, the building at the core of today's palace was a large townhouse built for the Duke of Buckingham in 1703. It was acquired by King George III in 1761 as a private residence for Queen Charlotte and became known as The Queen's House. During the 19th century, it was enlarged, primarily by architects John Nash and Edward Blore, who constructed three wings around a central courtyard. Buckingham Palace became the London residence of the British monarch on the accession of Queen Victoria in 1837. The last major structural additions were made in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including the East Front, which contains the well-known balcony on which the royal family traditionally congregates to greet crowds. reference: Edinburgh Castle is a historic fortress which dominates the skyline of Edinburgh, Scotland, from its position on the Castle Rock. Archaeologists have established human occupation of the rock since at least the Iron Age, although the nature of the early settlement is unclear. There has been a royal castle on the rock since at least the reign of David I in the 12th century, and it continued to be a royal residence until 1633. From the 15th century, the castle's importance as a royal residence declined, and by the time of the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, it was principally used as military barracks with a large garrison. Its importance as a part of Scotland's national heritage was increasingly recognised from the early 19th century onwards, and various restoration programmes have been carried out since. As one of the most important strongholds in the Kingdom of Scotland, Edinburgh Castle was involved in many historical conflicts, including the Wars of Scottish Independence and the Jacobite rising of 1745. It is now a major tourist attraction and forms part of the Old and New Towns of Edinburgh's World Heritage Site.

reference: St. Peter's Basilica is a Renaissance-era church located in Vatican City, an independent city-state enclaved within Rome, Italy. It is the largest church in the world and one of the holiest Catholic shrines. It is traditionally the burial site of its titular, Saint Peter, one of the twelve apostles of Jesus and the first Bishop of Rome. St. Peter's is famous for its dome, designed by Michelangelo, and is a symbol of the Catholic Church.
